body:
Possible duplicate of #11231 and thereby #2381

@Kudostoy0u it's possible - if you have a terminal which supports ANSI escape codes. It's not easy to implement for PowerShell because of backwards compatibility and terminal / Windows API / .Net / cross-platform compatibility.

ANSI escape codes are supported in [Windows 10 build 18298 console](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/commandline/new-experimental-console-features/) and [Windows Terminal](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/commandline/introducing-windows-terminal/) and there are some examples [here](https://duffney.io/usingansiescapesequencespowershell/#8-bit-256-color-foreground-background) and [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56679782/how-to-use-ansi-escape-sequence-color-codes-for-psreadlineoption-v2-in-powershel) about using them for more colours and 24-bit colours.

e.g.

```powershell
PS C:\> $e = [char]0x1b
>> "$e[38;2;255;128;128;48;2;128;0;255;4mtest$e[0m"
test    # in pink and purple and underlined
```
